PROGRAM OFFERING
NAEB NETWORK
Series 54~21 (Summer 1954)
5-10-54
PROGRAM OFFERING
Title: AIR TRAINING
Typo: Documentary (On-the-spot recorded)
Time: 29:15
No*: 13 progs
Origin: Office of Information Services8
Air Training Command
The producers of this series describe it thus:
•'This is not a recruiting series* It paints no glowing pictureso
It presents AF training as it actually exists, told in the voices of
young man and women who are learning to become pilots, or bombardiers*
or truck drivers, or radio operators,,or any of the hundreds of
military and professional skills needed by the Air Force* Each program
is designed to be informative and educational, completely free from
any reference aimed directly at seeking Air Force enlistments« So far
as can be determined, such a program series has never been made avail¬
able before to educational radio stations by any of the services* The
very impact of presenting Air Force training as it actually occurs
makes the series different*
Virtually every male student of high school or college age faces
military service* Also, many young women are seeking a career or an
assignment to one of the services* This sories will be most interesting
to them and their instructors and families, because it is designed to
tell them exactly what could happen to them should they go into the
Air Force, pointing out not only the practices that may be most desirable
and pleasant to the airman, but also recognising the things v?hich may
not be entirely to his liking*
It is "dramatic” in the sense that it has recorded the emotions
of the young recruit first learning to march and to salute, th© young
jet pilot's first take-off, the observers practice in bombing and
navigating, and the WAF1s initial frustration at finding herself in a
world formerly occupied only by males. They are true emotions, because
they have come from a realistic stimulation***the documents were recorded
on the spot**•as they happened* They are the direct result of an
earnest attempt to present both the good he bad, the simple and th©
difficult, the humorous and the serious p of each phase of Air Force
Training*
Each program in the series is complete within itself, and its
programming can ba planned independently of any others* If some
station should riot desire to broadcast the complete series of thirteen
programs, those that they do choose can be broadcast without any loss
of continuity*
The series was prepared by the Oral Productions Section of the
Office of Information Services for the Air Training Command* The
production was under the direst supervision of Mr, Russell Wagner, the
chief of the section, with aid and assistance from skilled radio tech¬
nicians recruited from installations throughout the Command* The
quality of the series is something that cannot be described adequately
